characters: SHELLS, SUNFLOWERS, PLANTS, RAM HORNS, HUMAN FINGERPRINTS
IN FRONT OF MAX'S APARTMENT BUILDING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max jolts his head from his desk and tries to orient him- in the darkness. He has intelligent eyes set in an exhaus good-looking face. Then he notices the blood dripping from his nose. Max wip it. Max's voiceover begins:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monday, September first.  Six-fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pull-string light flips on. Max examines his bloody nos the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The alchemist awakes.  (Imitating)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Turn lead into gold, Max,  lead into gold." Today, I find it.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON
dialogues.text: Max's hand as three unmarked, circular pills hit his palm Then, he slams the pills into the back of his mouth. Max replaces the cap on a plastic bottle of unmarked  prescription drugs. He drinks from the sink and splashes generous amount of water onto his head and face, cleaning nose. He wipes his nose and examines the last remnants of blood his fingertip. Then, he dips his finger under the tap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max's room is constantly dark because the windows are bla out. He flips on his desk lamp. A tiny ANT crawls across his desk. He looks at it for a m before getting angry and squashing it. Sitting on the desk are three computer monitors, which Ma flips on. Then he pops on more lights and more switches. We pull ba revealing that Max's apartment looks more like the inside computer than a human's home. The room is knee-high in computer parts of all shapes and sizes. The walls are covered with circuit boards. Cables from the ceiling like vines in a Brazilian rain forest. T all seem to be wired together forming a monstrous homemad computer. This is EUCLID, Max's creation. The computer is alive wit sounds and lights. Max works on Euclid with his solder and drill. He cares f the machine as if it were his dream car

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heat's been getting  to Euclid. Feel it most in  the afternoon when I run the  set. Have to keep the fans on  all night from now on.  Otherwise, everything is  running topnotch. The stack  of 286's is now faster than  Columbia's computer science  department. I spent a couple  hundred dollars. Columbia's  cost? Half a million?  (Small snicker)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max checks the peephole on His front door. No one is ther unbolts the five lock and slides into the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he secures his apartment, a Young girl named JENNA run to him. Her MOM, down the hall, looks apologetic. Jenna's eyes light up and she pulls out her Fisher Price  calculator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max, Max! Can we do one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Over and over again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenna! Jenna!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's three hundred  and twenty-two times four  hundred and ninety-one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenna types it into her calculator. Max finishes locking door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (instantly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One hundred fifty-eight thousand,  a hundred two. Right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Eyes light up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max heads down the staircase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenna...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenna screams after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, seventy-three  divided by twenty-two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (instantly again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three point three one eight one  eight one eight...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max watches people bustle through the busy intersections Chinatown. The streets are clogged with people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somewhere in there.  Somewhere. I know it's right  in front of me. The pattern.  They say it's chaos, it can't  be understood, too much  complexity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max scavenges electronic parts as he carefully navigates endless dump for old and rotting computers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: History it's there.  Lurking, shaping.  structuring, hiding, right  beneath the surface. He unscrews a random IBM Board from a keyboard and slides into his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: MOVE IN
dialogues.text: on Max looking up at something as he reclines on a public bench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cycling of disease epidemics,  the wax and wane of Caribou populations  in the Arctic, sunspot cycles,  the rise and fall of the  Nile and yes! the New York Stock  Exchange, they are all the  same.

dialogues.speaker: MOVE IN
dialogues.text: on a tree branch - shaking gently in the wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bright stock quotes drift across the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll find this structure,  this order, this perfection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max stares intensely at the ticker on the small TV that s next to his monitors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn lead into gold.  The first. Right here. Right  here. With math. The numbers  of the stock market are my  lead. When I find the  pattern, then I will find  gold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max watches the right edge of the screen where the number appear. He wants to see what's before that edge... Max slaps the RETURN button on his computer. The phone starts ringing. Max eyes it suspiciously. Just then, Euclid starts printing results on an old dot- matrix printer. Max suspiciously answers The phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maximilian Cohen, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Cohen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. my name is Marcy Dawson.  I'm a partner with the predictive  strategy firm Lancet-Percy. Can I  speak with Mr. Cohen, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The printer finishes printing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Cohen! How  are you? It's been a long  time. Sorry I haven't been in  touch. But I was hoping you  would allow me to take you to  lunch tomorrow, say one  o'clock?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're very anxious to talk  with you, sir

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm prepared to  make you a generous... Max hurries to wrap up the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't take offers for  my research. You know that.  Sorry, I Couldn't help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Cohen, give  me a moment... But before Marcy finishes, Max hangs up. He rips off the  printout and heads to the front door. He checks the peephole, His landlady. MRS. OVADIA, is swe the hallway stairs humming a turn-of-the century (the las one, not this one) tune. Max waits a moment. He tousles his hair. Then he checks a She's gone. He opens his locks and releases several bolts

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max locks his front door. Meanwhile, his next-door neighb DEVI MINSTRY, a sexy young Indian woman, is just getting Max looks away and tries to get his door locked. She's weighted down by a bunch of bags filled with food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max, good!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Devi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I grabbed you some  somosas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Devi heads over to Max with her bags of food. She looks u Max.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Devi hands the bags to Max. Then she goes to pat down his Hair. Max retreats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your hair, you can't go  out like that. Don't worry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fine. It's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Devi pats down his hair. Max is humiliated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need a mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max hands back the bags and heads quickly for the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your somosas!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An embarrassed Max takes the bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the counter, Max stirs cream into his coffee. Then he three pills from the plastic bottle and drops them in his coffee. Max flips past a full-page ad in the paper that reads

dialogues.speaker: LANCET-PERCY 86
dialogues.text: Max flips the page before he or we can absorb it. He comp stock quotes in the Wall Street Journal against his print

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixteen, twenty-seven. Results: Euclid  shows tomorrow's Dow closing  up by four points. Anomalies  include PRONET at sixty-fire  and a quarter, a career high.  Possible explanations, either  A, an error in the June fifth  algorithm, or B, Euclid's  main processor is running a  recursion... Max marks up the paper with lines and diagrams as he pond his bits and misses. Then a puff of cigarette smoke drifts by and succeeds in  bothering Max. He fans it away whenВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh sorry, am I bothering you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max shrugs and looks over. The voice belongs to LENNY MEYERВ—a bearded man in his la sucking on a cigarette. On closer inspection, something is off. It seems that Len an Orthodox Jew. His yarmulke sticks out Slightly from hi wide-brimmed hat and the fringes from his tsi-tsis hang o from the bottom of his untucked shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll put it out.  (Which he does)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The name's Lenny Meyer

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lenny sticks out his hand. Max responds with a small nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max Cohen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cohen!  (Judging)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jewish?  Max shrugs and turns back to his work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay.  (Joking)  I'm a Jew, too.  (Serious)  Do you practice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not interested  in religion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever  heard of Kabbalah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jewish mysticism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I'm very busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand...it's just that  it's a very exciting time in  our history. Right now is a  critical moment in time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sarcastic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it's very exciting.  Have you ever put on Tefillin? Max has no idea what Lenny's talking about. Lenny pulls a leather box with black leather straps from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tefillin. You know Tefillin.  I know it looks strange.  But it's an amazing  tradition that has a  tremendous amount of power.  It's a mitzvah for all  Jewish men to do. Mitzvahs,  good deeds, are spiritual  food for our hearts and our  heads. And then Max notices that his thumb is twitching He grabs self-consciously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They purify us and bring us  closer to God. You want to try it? Just then, Max pays his bill and prepares to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you okay? Max? Max?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe some other time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max splashes water on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please God, Let it be a  small one. He pulls a metal vaccinating gun out of the medicine cabi Then be loads it with a small bottle of medicine. He roll his sleeve, dabs alcohol on his arm, and fires the gun in his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixteen thirty-five.  Second headache in under  twenty-four hours. They're  getting more frequent  now...more painful, too. Drugs  don't work, just take the  edge off of it. Just gotta  wait for the nosebleed.  Relief comes from my nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next door, he hears Devi and her boyfriend talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I gotta make this drop off  in Harlem and on the way down  there's these three kids  hailing me. Max slaps himself in the face a few times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stopped?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was tight, so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max watches his thumb twitch. And then pain shoots throug him. He grabs the right side of his head, massages it, an pushes it in with his fingers. In the mirror, he examines the right side of his scalp. H sees nothing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max walks back into the

dialogues.speaker: MAIN ROOM
dialogues.text: and sits down in a chair. The lamp is blinding so he snaps it off. Only the bathroom light lights the room. He takes a few breaths.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave me alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His neighbors conversation begins to build in volume and distortion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I drop them off in the  Village and they dart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max gags and rubs his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get out, grab my bat and  start running. One of the kids,  maybe sixteen, I catch a block  later he's cursing at me, calling  me a Paki bastard. So I whacked him,  right in the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Farrouhk!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pain seems to disappear. Max looks at his hand that w rubbing his bead. Then he looks at the front door. The doorknob seems to move.  Something begins knocking on Max's door. The knocking get louder and louder then the locks begin to unlock. FARROUHK's words begin to overpower Max.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm kicking the bastard in the  ribs banging his ass, knocking his  head against the curb, harder  and harder, I fucking lost  it. A hot dog guy starts  screaming "You're cracking his  skull, you're cracking his  skull." So they pulled me off  of him and calmed me down.  Cops said he had it coming to  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then something starts pounding the door. The doorknob qui the locks unbolt. The chains are the only thing keeping o the intruder. The door shakes and the chains are strained MAX is paralyzed with terror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then the door smashes open. Blinding light fills the and we crash into the

dialogues.speaker: BLINDING WHITE VOID
dialogues.text: A moment of silence, then we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A phone rings incessantly. Max's eyes pop open. He's scru up in a corner of the room, squashed beneath the sink. His nose is bleeding. Max, crawls into the

dialogues.speaker: MAIN ROOM
dialogues.text: and picks up the phone. He pinches his nose and tilts his back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Cohen. Marcy  Dawson here again I was just  looking over my schedule and  I realized I'll be in your  neighborhood tomorrow around  three. Max heads to the

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: and checks the locks. He is barely listening to Marcy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Groggy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The locks seem secure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcy Dawson from  Lancet-Percy I'm so anxious  to meet you. It will be worth  itВ—for both of us I promise.  See you at your house at  three, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My house...how do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, don't worry,  I got your address from  Columbia. So three it is.  Looking forward to it. Max tries to stop her but, before he can Marcy hangs up. A bewildered Max slowly hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max checks the peephole - all clear. Then, he opens his -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: which is filled with random computer parts and boxes. He pulls a thick neuroscience book from a shelf in the ba the closet. He almost knocks over an old dusty brass  microscope on the shelf. Max flips through the book. It contains old plates  illustrating the brain. Max examines some of the diagrams EXT. S0L'S HALLWAY - DAY Max rings the bell on an apartme door. A few moments pass, and then SOL ROBESON opens the door. Sol is a wise-looking man in his early 70's. He walks wit difficulty, leaning out of breath on a wooden cane. His arms are covered with faded Russian prison tattoos an speaks with a thick Eastern European accent, He's happy t Max.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max! How are you7

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max is happy to see Sol, but he's a bit bashful and  intimidated. MAX Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT ON the Japanese game of Go being played. Sol is whi and Max is black. Sol's moves are secure and controlled w Max is hesitant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop thinking, Max, just  feel. Use your intuition.  It's the only way to get into  the flow.  (Beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you think of Hamlet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't get to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been a month.  (Knowingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't taken  a single break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so close, Sol. I'm  so close but I just can't  grab it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sol changes the subject. He feeds his goldfish and points one of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you met the new  fish my niece bought me? I  named her Icarus. After you.  My renegade pupil. You fly  too high, you'll get burned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max looks up at Sol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The more I see you, the  more I see myself thirty  years ago. My greatest pupil.  Published at 16, Ph.D. at 20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But life isn't just  mathematics. I spent forty  years looking for patterns in  Pi, I found nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You found things...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found things, but not a  pattern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max sits in the corner of a rickety New York City subway The train is almost completely deserted. Max looks down at his hand. He opens his palm and reveals black Go chip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tuesday, September  second, eighteen twelve. If  Sol hadn't gotten sick who  knows where math would be. He  spent years in the numbers of  Pi. Searching for meaning, for  order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max notices a SKINNY MAN in a business suit staring at hi The man catches Max's eye and looks away, but then he qui looks back, making Max turn away. He looks down at his Wall Street journal and draws a circ with its diameter then he writes "A=pir2" and "C=2pir." N he writes "pi=3.14159..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three point one  four...off into infinity  and maybe insanity. Somewhere  in there he wanted sanity.  Sanity like he found in the  circles Pi represented.  Simple, sane circles. If only  the stock market had circles.  Some type of sanity. Some  type of form, of shape. Suddenly, Max hears someone singing. Max looks up. It is Skinny Man and he's singing with passion. It's all very  strange to Max, who nervously looks away. And then the singing stopsВ— mid-verse Max looks up and the man is gone. Vanished. Max looks aroundВ—no one in Sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max heads up the stairs to his apartment. Just then, a to SLINKY appears from nowhere marching down the stairs. Max stops and waits until the Slinky hits his foot. He pi it up and looks at it. He looks around wondering what's going on. Then Jenna lea out over a railing and starts laughing at Max.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max sits at the counter frantically looking at the Wall S Journal. He plops three pills into his coffee. He draws circles and other shapes across the page. Max is interrupted by a puff of smoke. At the same time,  someone touches his shoulder and says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Max, how you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lenny Meyer.  (Motioning to the cigarette)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll put it out.  (Which be does)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, I work with computers  ...math.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? What type of math?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number theory. Mostly  research.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number theory? No  way, I work in theory, too.  Not traditional, though... (Points to his yarmulke)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I work with the Torah.  (Awed by the coincidence)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amazing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Passing it of as a coincidence)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. You know Hebrew is  all numbers. It's all math.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lenny pulls out a worn' dog-eared Bible from his pocket. are paper slips marking what seems like every other page. he opens it up, Max sees that the pages are marked up by highlighter pens notes and diagrams. Lenny points to the text. EXTREME CLOSE-UP of Hebrew lett

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, look...the ancient  Jews used Hebrew as their  numerical system. Each  letter is a number. Lenny pulls out a pen and grabs Max's Journal. He writes as he talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see...The Hebrew "A," the  number 1. The Hebrew "B,"  Bet, is two. You can take any  Hebrew text and turn them into  a long string of numbers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waitress refills Max's coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Torah is just  a long string of numbers.  Some say that it's a long  code sent to us from God. Satisfied, Lenny lights up a cigarette and takes a drag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Mildly impressed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kind of interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Proud of himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, like take the  Hebrew word for, say, the  Garden of Eden, Kadem. Kuf,  Dalei Mem...Kuf is a  hundred. Daled, four Mem,  forty. They equal one hundred  and forty-four. Then take the  tree of knowledge...in  the garden, Aat Ha Haim, it  equals two hundred and  thirty-three. Now you can take  that number and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're Fibonacci numbers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Fibonacci sequence.  Italian mathematician, thirteenth century. If you divide  a hundred and forty-four into  two hundred and thirty-three,  it approaches theta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theta?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Greek symbol for the  golden ratio. The golden  spiral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lenny exhales the smoke. Max quickly graphs the number on Wall Street Journal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right, I never saw  that before. That's the series  you find in nature. Like the  face of a sunflower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wherever there's spirals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, there's math everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lenny's smoke drifts by Max's eyes. SLOW MOTION: MAX'S POV of smoke spirals spinning in front him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Math everywhere...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLOW MOTION: Max looks down at his coffee cup. He pours c into his coffee. It shoots up and mixes with the black co forming spirals in the mug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Serious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everywhere...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLOW MOTION: Max looks at the spiral he just drew on the Street Journal. NORMAL SPEED Suddenly, Max stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max draws spirals all over his Wall Street Journal. Then takes a thick black marker and draws a giant spiral acros entire page. Max is ecstatic as he pounds code into the computer takes moments to wake up, drops pills, and drinks a Ginseng sod

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simple shapes!  Tuesday, September second.  Twenty-twenty-two. Sol! Sol!  Sol! Shapes in the market.  Why not? And they're spirals!  Spirals! Max traces a big circle on the journal. Then, he cuts it with an X-acto blade. He cuts out the middle of the circl that be has a thin loop like one of those futuristic fris He tears part of the loop and stretches the circle out in front of him into a spiral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A circle spread out overtime.  It's open-ended. It has a  beginning and it grows and  changes through time. If I  can find where it fits, if I  can spin it and lock it into  a group of numbers, then I  can calculate the future.  Lead into gold. Chaos into  order Madness into sanity. Pain  into bliss. Perfection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max is about to slap RETURN but he stops himselfВ—he's ne Next door, Devi and her boyfriend are making love. He loo the wall with disdain. Then he looks back at the screen,  shrugs and confidently slaps RETURN on his keyboard. Stock prices float across the screen. Max can't believe h eyesВ—the quotes are absurd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then, Euclid crashes. The electricity in Max's room f off. The numbers on Max's screen fade to black. In near ( streetlights) darkness:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit!

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON A FUSE BOX
dialogues.text: Max removes a fuse. He replaces it with a penny.

dialogues.speaker: MAX'S ROOM
dialogues.text: Max tries to reboot Euclid, but nothing happens. He tries second time, but nothing happens. Devi and Farrouhk are still at it. Max puts on a pair of latex gloves. He dons a surgical ma He climbs up to a loft above his monitors. A glass case, cool air by a vent tube, encases some computer parts. He  carefully removes the front glass cover. Then he gets it off he's stunned. Not only have the chips melted down, but a strange flaky substance covers the boa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max grabs his face, frustrated. Deri and Farroakk are giggling, having a great time. Max  stares at the wall. Then he angrily throws Euclid's mainframe onto the ground lands with a SMASH! Under the mainframe is a small city of ANTS. They scrambl cover. Max furiously attacks them, stomping them out with bands. Then he jumps on the smashed mainframe. He slides to the ground and covers his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT ON a tree branch shaking manically in the wind. Max sits on a park bench watching the branch shake. It  terrifies him. He pulls out the printout of his picks and examines them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wednesday, September third,  seven-fifteen. Results: AAR  at fourteen and a halfВ—low,  very low. ABR at six and a  halfВ—jeez. Six and a half, ABR  hasn't been beneath twenty in  ten years. Conclusion:  Simple. There is no pattern.  No pattern. Chaos, chaos, all  chaos. He crumples up his picks and tosses them into a public tr can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sol and Max play Go. Sol is peaceful while Max is distant Max plays a piece absently. Sol counters with a deafening atari. Max whispers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Euclid crashed. I lost  all my data, my hardware.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mainframe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burnt...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, first I got  these horrible picks. Then  Euclid spits out some  numbers. Never saw anything  like it and then it fries.  The whole machine just  crashed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a printout?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The picks, the number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I threw it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was the number it  spit out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, just a long  string of digits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Intense)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was it, a  hundred and fifty, a  thousand, two hundred  sixteen!? How many?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Probably  around two hundred.  (Wondering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Beat)...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dealt with  some bugs back in my Pi days.  I was wondering if it was  similar to one I ran into. Sol begins to feed his fish. He points to one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you met Archimedes.  The one with the black spot.  You see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember Archimedes of  Syracuse? The King asks  Archimedes to determine if a  present he's received was  actually solid gold. Unsolved  problem at the time. It  tortures the great Greek  mathematician for weeks.  Insomnia haunts him and he  twists and turns on his bed  for nights on end. Finally,  his equally exhausted wife,  she's forced to share a bed  with this genius, convinces  him to take a bath, to relax.  While stepping into the tub  he observes the bathwater  rise as he enters. Displacement.  A way to determine volume.  And thus, a way to  determine density, weight  over volume. And thus,  Archimedes solves the  problem. He screams  "Eureka!"В—Greek for "I found  it!"В—and is so overwhelmed he  runs dripping naked through  the streets to the King's  castle to report his  discovery. Now, what's the  moral of the story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That a breakthrough will  come...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrong. The point of the  story is the wife. Listen to  your wife, she will give you  perspective. Meaning, you  need a break, Max, you have  to take a bath, otherwise  you'll get nowhere. There will  be no order, only chaos.  Go home and take a bath.

dialogues.speaker: PUBLIC BENCH
dialogues.text: Max waits for his train on an empty platform. Just then, he hears a DRIPPING sound. Max looks up and no something across the tracks on the other platform. He can quite make it out because his vision is blocked by column He gets up and spots a Young Hasidic Man standing at him. Blood drips from the Man's hand. Max doesn't know what to of it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max reads an ad that says In big block letters 'MOSHIAC I COMING!' He checks out a few of the other passengers. The notices a man reading a newspaper across from him. The headline reads: 'MARKET TAKES NOSE-DIVE. Max jumps up approaches the man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, excuse me, can I see  that? The man hands Max the paper. Max scans the article. Then quickly turns to the listings. His finger barrels down a  column. It stops at ABR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six and a half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max looks up the column for AAR. MAX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fourteen and a half. Oh,  my... Max stumbles toward the doors. He looks out the window: i the darkness of the tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Out of breath)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God. My God.  (Gets pumped to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, paper, please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max hands the paper back and looks at the man for the fir time. It is the Skinny Man he saw earlier. Max gets suspicious and moves into the next car.

dialogues.speaker: AT GRAND STREET
dialogues.text: Max exits. He notices that the Skinny Man gets off - one down - as well. He hustles toward the exit. As he's about to turn a corne looks back. The man seems to be following him. He dodges around a corner and heads up a staircase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He seems to have lost him, when he notices a business-wom with a pretty face heading right toward him. It is MARCY  DAWSON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Cohen! Perfect timing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcy sticks out her hand. Max, not knowing what else to shakes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just waiting for you.  I thought you stood me up,  so I was going to head home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh...Marcy Dawson. From  Lancet Percy. We were  supposed to meet at three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I don't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcy hasn't let go of Max's hand. She guides him toward a large black street limo that's ju pulled up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't tell you what a  pleasure it is to finally  meet you. I've studied  your papers for years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have something  you won't be able to say no  to. Why don't we take a spin  in the limo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no, really, I  can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're excited by your work.  We can't wait to discuss... Max attempts to pull away but Marcy is firm on leading hi the car. Meanwhile, the Shinny man is heading right at th The CHAUFFEUR reaches out to him. Max yanks his arm free runs away. He whips around a corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max barrels into the grocery store and buys a Journal. He heads to the back of the store and lays the paper across juice section. He checks the listing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the nose. On the damn nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max turns the page on the Journal and sees the Lancet-Per ad. Then he notices one of the bodega owners staring at h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max scouts his front door. The coast is clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max examines the smashed Euclid mainframe. He uncovers so the strange filo-like substance. He carefully touches it. he grabs a small pinch of it. He examines it near a light bulb. He can't guess what it He sniffs it. He carefully tastes it with the very tip of tongue. He still doesn't have a clue. Max opens his closet. He pulls out his dusty brass micros He dusts it off. Next, he pulls out a slide Kit. Max places the instrument on the windowsill. He grabs an glass slide and puts some of the flaky stuff on it. He sl it under the microscope. He looks into the lens, but does see anything. He gets up quickly and heads for the

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: where he looks at Devi's door, nervously. He gathers his  courage and knocks on her door. Through the door hears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Farrouhk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, no, it's Max from next door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Devi opens the door wearing a sexy nightshirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max, is everything all  right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any iodine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (concerned, she reaches for Max's hands)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iodine...did you cut  yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Pulling his hands away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I just need it to stain a  slide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, science, the pursuit  of knowledge. One second. She heads to her bathroom. Max waits impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we are. What are you  examiningВ— (At the door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a potato!? She hands Max a bottle of iodine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just something with my  computer.

dialogues.speaker: MAX'S ROOM
dialogues.text: Max uses his pinky to drip a drop of iodine on the slide. Through the wall he hears Farrouhk arriving home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The neighbor's up  to his old science...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What neighbor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max listens to the conversation for a few moments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you talking to that dork!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shh! I just helped ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pounds on wall. Hey, dork, leave my girlfriend alone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Farrouhk!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max shakes his bead. Then he finishes preparing the slide slips the glass under the turret. Max catches the low-hanging sun in the microscope's mirro reflects it through the sample and up the turret into his eye. MAX'S POV DOWN THE TURRET of some strange Substance. Max pulls out the slide and looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't give a shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shh! C'mon, Farrouhk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll kill the dork.  (Exploding again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hear me! I'll kill you.  I'll fucking kill you! Then an idea comes to him. He takes out his brain book. H looks through it until he finds a picture of neurons. He  compares the image to the view through the turret. They l different but there are similarities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shh! Baby! Come here, baby!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max rushes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max sifts through the trash can where he threw his picks yesterday. Frustrated, he dumps the trash onto the sidewa and starts looking through it Mrs. Ovadia watches him. Max sees her and is embarrassed for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just threw out something.  I didn't realize I needed it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Humph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a printout. I, uh,  lost my data... Max looks back at the trash And forgets about Mrs. Ovadia Soon, Max gets up and kicks the trashcan. He heads home.

dialogues.speaker: IN FRONT OF MAX'S APARTMENT BUILDING
dialogues.text: Max watches Marcy get out of the limo and call to Mrs. Ov Max backs away when he smacks into someone. It's Lenny Meyer - the young Jewish man. Max jumps back in fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max! How you doing? Lenny  Meyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max tries to quickly pass him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, where you going? You  got a few moments to do Tefillin? Max turns around and notices Marcy talking to Mrs. Ovadia Mrs. Ovadia points up the street toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta car, we can cruise  over to my...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, right there. That's  Ephraim, my friend. We swing around with Max and see a station wagon. EPHRAIM sits in the passenger Seat. He's a big-boned, bea Orthodox Jew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All tight, lets go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They head for the station wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The synagogue is a claustrophobic, fluorescent-lit room i general disarray. Two rows of imitation-wooden pews face makeshift altar and Ark. Young Hasidic Men study texts. S work alone, reading and dovening. Others are in small gro sharing in heated discussions. Lenny wraps the Tefillin around Max's arm. Max just wants get out of there. Ephraim prays in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lenny, I don't really  want to do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it for me? It  means a lot, having someone  of your stature performing a  mitzvah in my presence.  (Beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you told me your name was Max Cohen, I didn't realize you  were the Max Cohen. Maximilian Cohen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 0f course, I've  followed your research since  your Columbia days. It's  revolutionary. You've inspired  the work we do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, very much  so. The only difference is,  we're not looking at stocks.  We're searching for a pattern  in Torah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lenny finishes wrapping Max's arm. He reaches for another and strap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of pattern?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not really  sure. Our calculations have  shown us that there is a  number encoded in the text.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What sort of number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't know.  All we know is that it's two hundred and sixteen digits long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max, stunned looks at Lenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. This one just  goes over your head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lenny places the other Teffilin over Max's head. Max coll himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Coolly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two sixteen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Now we have to say a  small prayer, repeat  after me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bewildered, Max does. After the prayer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it. Wasn't  so bad, was it? You feel  anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lenny starts removing the Teffillin from Max.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a prayer about our  dedication to our one and  only God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Attempting calmness)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I mean the number, the  two sixteen number? What is  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. We don't know. We just  know that it's the most  common number encoded in  the text. It might be some  type of linguistic pattern.  If we could figure out what  the number is we could maybe  answer that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max firmly rings SOL's bell. In a few moments, Sol answers the door in his pajamas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on, Sol!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax, it's early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max sits at the kitchen table while Sol heats up a pot of Max is shaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, what's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the two hundred  and sixteen number, Sol?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You asked me if I had  seen a two hundred and  sixteen digit number, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you mean the bug. I  found it working on Pi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean by "found it"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this all about,  Max?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there's these  religious Jews who have...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Religious Jews?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you know,  Hassidim. I met one in the  coffee shop. The guy's a  number theorist. The Torah is  their data set. The thing is,  they're searching for a two  hundred and sixteen digit  number in the Torah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? What's it mean to  them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say they don't  know, but that's crazy. I  mean what are the odds...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just a coincidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But hold on, there's  something else. You remember  those strange picks I got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yesterday's stock picks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Well, it turns out  that they were correct. I hit  two picks on the nose. Smack  on the nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something's going on, and  it has to do with that  number. The answer is there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max, it's a bug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. it's a pattern. A  pattern is in that number

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sol and Max sit on either side of a half-played Go board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me. The Ancient  Japanese considered the Go  board to be a microcosm of  the universe. Although when  it is empty it appears to be  simple and ordered, in fact,  the possibilities of game play  are endless. They say that no  two Go games have ever been  alike. Just like snowflakes.  So, the Go board actually  represents an extremely complex  and chaotic universe. That is  the truth of our world, Max.  It can't be easily summed up  with math. There is no simple  pattern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But as a Go game  progresses, the possibilities  become smaller and smaller.  The board does take on order.  Soon, all moves are  predictable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, maybe, even though we're not  sophisticated enough to be aware  of it, there is an underlying  order...a pattern, beneath every  Go game. Maybe that pattern is  like the pattern in the market,  in the Torah. The two sixteen  number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is insanity, Max.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or maybe it's genius. I  have to get that number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on, you have to slow  down. You're losing it, you have to take a breath. Listen  to yourself. You're connecting  a computer bug I had, a  computer bug you might have  had, and some religious  hogwash. If you want to find  the number two sixteen in the  world, you'll be able to pull  it out of anywhere. Two  hundred and sixteen steps  from your street comer to  your front door. Two hundred  and sixteen seconds you spend  riding on the elevator. When  your mind becomes obsessed  with anything, it will filter  everything else out and find  examples of that thing  everywhere. Three hundred and  twenty, four hundred and  fifty, twenty-three.  Whatever! You've chosen two  sixteen and you'll find it  everywhere in nature. But  Max, as soon as you discard  scientific rigor, you are no  longer a mathematician. You  become a numerologist. What  you need to do is take a  break from your research. You  need it. You deserve it  Here's a hundred dollars, I  want you to take it. If ,you  won't take it, borrow it.  Either way, take a break. Spend it however you like as  long as it falls in the  category of vacation. Real  world stuff, okay. No math. Max looks at his bands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just try it. In a week  you'll laugh about this.  C'mon, Max. Think about it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max gives a half nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max rushes to the subway when a honking horn stops him. A pulls up next to him. Marcy Dawson jumps out of the car

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Cohen? Mr.  Cohen? Please stop for a  second Mr. Cohen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max stops and faces Marcy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn it already! Stop  following me. I'm not  interested in your money. I'm  searching for a way to  understand our world. I'm  searching for perfection. I  don't deal with mediocre  materialistic people like  you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I'm very sorry.  I admit I've been a bit too  aggressive. But all I ask is  for five minutes of your time.  Here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcy hands Max a metal stopwatch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...a stopwatch.  Already ticking. Allow me the  four and a half minutes left  Let me tell you what I want.  Let me tell you what I can  offer you. Afterwards, if you  don't want to talk to me, then  fine, we part as friends and  I promise that you will never  see me again. That's fair,  isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (After a moment, he looks at the stopwatch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. It's funny,  even though we have different  aims and different goals  we're actually incredibly  alike. We both seek the same  thingВ—perfection. I know... clearly we're seeking  different types of  perfection, but that is what  makes us perfect candidates  for a fruitful partnership.  If you let me, I can be your  greatest ally. Take the  acacia tree...in East  Africa. It is the most  prevalent plant in all of  Kenya because it has managed  to secure its niche by  defeating its major predator,  the giraffe. To accomplish  this, the tree has made a contract  with a highly specialized red ant.  The tree has evolved giant spores which  act as housing for the ants  In return for shelter, the  ants supply defense. When a  giraffe starts to eat the  tree's leaves, the shaking  branch acts like an alarm. The  ants charge out and secrete an  acid onto the giraffe's  tongue. The giraffe learns its  lesson and never returns.  Without each other, the tree  would be picked dry and the  ants would have no shade from  the brutal African sun Both  would die. But with each  other, they succeed, they survive,  they surpass. They have  different aims, different  goals but they work together. Max, we would like to establish  a mutually benefiting alliance  with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing back the stopwatch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allow me to dose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chauffeur pulls a black suitcase out of the limo and  brings it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a sign of good faith we  wish to offer you this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you I don't want money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The suitcase isn't filled with  fifties or gold or diamonds. Just  silicon. A Ming Mecca chip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Yeah right!)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ming Mecca. They're not declassified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max starts to move away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
